Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about the evolution of fashion, historical writing, and analysis.

I learned a lot about fashion in the context of history, as well as how to closely analyze clothing and historical/sociological essays/articles. I would like to note that the course's primary focus is on fashion over different time periods, rather than aesthetics.

I learned so much about history in London and Paris and how it correlates to fashion. It is a fascinating course if you're interested in fashion and the arts, but I think anyone should take it! I wish they offered more fashion history classes here at Yale.
I learned all about the history of fashion.

By taking History 033 I definitely learnt a lot about fashion. The material was not boring and the readings and discussions included truly diverse topics. However, throughout the course, I also developed skills in research and I also feel much more confident when writing academic papers.

I learned a lot about critical historical discussion. I learned a lot about the fashion industry and how to draw connections to history. I feel like I can not only talk about fashion, but history with more confidence.
I gained analytical skills and learned how to analyze historical context.
Learned about the vast history of womens fashion in Paris and London.
Further insight into the history of fashion, specifically its relationship with various social movements and historical events.

I think the subject matter was fascinating and very well presented. Most of the classes consisted of us discussing readings, so it was a very interest-guided curriculum. This was also expressed in our essay topics, since we had a lot of flexibility for each one. I also really enjoyed the "field trips" in this course, as they introduced me to museums I probably wouldn't have visited otherwise and also allowed us to see the material applied in a really cool way. The only downside was that some of the readings were pretty long, but overall I think the strengths of this course overshadow the weaknesses.

I definitely enjoyed the small class size, as it allowed for a lot of interaction between students--in fact, most classes were discussion-based. One strength is that the in-class participation is very high, although there is not a lot of work outside of class. I don't really have any criticisms of the class.

Strengths: a lot of course material, interesting conversations
Weaknesses: the structure was rather boring at times- we do the exact same thing every class
This course is well laid out, I don't have any complaints. It was a very fun class.
I really loved the presentation-discussion type of learning. It was interesting, engaging, and innovative at the same time.
Strengths are the intimate discussions. We had an incredible group and really grew as a class. Class was really engaging, with field trips and speakers! Weaknesses, the readings sometimes drag on.

The strengths were that we gained a deep understanding of a wide variety of fashion trends and social movements that accompanied them throughout history. The course was very well organized and helped us become comfortable with historical research.
A few of the reading assignments seemed not as important as others. But overall the class was very well put together.

The topics are very interesting and the University resources are used very well. I wish that the expertise of the professor was more utilized in the classroom. While the student presentations encouraged attentive reading of the course material, I found myself hoping that Professor Conekin would contribute more of her knowledge to the conversations.
Professor Conekin knows a lot about the history of fashion, however, it would be helpful if there were more professor led discussions.
There could be more interaction and contribution by the professor, instead of having mostly student-run discussions in class

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Based on my conversations with other first-years, this seminar is much more engaging, well-organized, and student-friendly than most other classes. It is also significantly less work than most other writing credits, which I highly appreciate.

I would definitely recommend this course. It is a writing credit, although there are only two essays--and for someone interested in the subject, the essays are not difficult to write. The workload is low, but the discussions in class are always interesting.

Yes- everyone should get a background into how consumer habits and fashion correlate to historical events, and this course is very relevant historically but also in the present. I believe more fashion history classes should be offered to Yale students.
I would because I enjoyed the class and looked forward to it every week.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in fashion.
Yes! There are not that many fashion courses offered - so this one is a gem. And prof. Conekin is amazing, not just as a professor but as a person. She helped all of us acclimate to college life.

I would recommend it to anyone that is passionate about fashion or who is interested in learning about the history of it. It was a very interesting and fun course and you get very close with your classmates and teacher.

Yes I would recommend taking this class. It fulfills a writing requirement while learning interesting material. The essay topics are all chosen my the students, leading to a more passionate experience.

Yes I would recommend it. The history of fashion is in many ways the history of the expression of social movements, and is a fascinating different angle on the way western society has changed in the last 250 years.
Not particularly, since most of the class was student run.
